alt_statements.statement: I think police should try really hard to be fair and kind to everyone, no matter what they look like or where they’re from, because that’s what Jesus teaches us about loving our neighbors. They should learn better ways to calm people down and talk things out before hurting anyone, but still be there to protect families and kids so we feel safe in our neighborhoods.

I think police should treat everyone fairly and with respect, no matter what they look like or where they come from, because God teaches us that everyone is equal and deserves kindness. They should get better training to calm situations down instead of going straight to force, and use cameras and clear rules so people can trust that they’re doing the right thing. At the same time, we still need police to keep our neighborhoods safe, so working together with the community and listening to kids and families can help everyone feel safer and more understood.

As someone who spent my career caring for people, I believe policing has to put human dignity and de-escalation first, especially for those who are vulnerable or often targeted by bias. We need stronger training in mental health and implicit bias, independent oversight of use-of-force, and clear consequences when officers violate policy. At the same time, communities should be partners in public safety, with more investment in social services and crisis responders so police aren’t the default answer for every problem. Real safety comes from trust, fairness, and making sure everyone is treated like their life matters.

As a young Black man, I’ve seen and felt how bias in policing can turn everyday situations dangerous for people who look like me, so reforms aren’t abstract—they’re about survival and dignity. We need stronger accountability for officers, better training in de-escalation and implicit bias, and more investment in community-based programs that prevent crime before it happens. Public safety shouldn’t mean over-policing certain neighborhoods; it should mean building trust so people feel safe calling the cops when they actually need help. I want a system where officers protect us, not profile us, and where that standard is enforced consistently.

Como alguien que valora el orden, la seguridad y la familia, creo que la policía es necesaria para mantener nuestras comunidades seguras, pero debe hacerlo con respeto y sin prejuicios. Se necesitan mejores entrenamientos en control de emociones, manejo de conflictos y trato justo a todas las personas, sin importar raza, idioma o estatus migratorio. También pienso que es importante que haya cámaras, supervisión y consecuencias claras cuando un oficial abusa de su autoridad, para que la comunidad pueda confiar en ellos. Si la policía trabaja con la comunidad, escucha a la gente y aplica la ley con firmeza pero con humanidad, se puede mantener la seguridad sin excesos de fuerza.

As someone who works hard, supports a family, and came to this country from Guatemala, I want policing that keeps our neighborhoods safe but treats everyone with dignity and fairness. Departments should invest in better training on de-escalation and bias, hire officers who actually reflect the communities they serve, and hold those who abuse their power truly accountable. At the same time, we need to support good officers with the resources and staffing they need so they can do their jobs safely and build trust instead of fear.

As a nurse who sees the consequences of violence and trauma up close, I believe policing strategies have to prioritize de-escalation, strong accountability, and thorough training on implicit bias and mental health crises. We need well-resourced alternatives for nonviolent situations—like mental health and social work teams—so officers can focus on genuine public safety threats. At the same time, I don’t want communities or officers left vulnerable, so reforms should aim to build mutual trust, clear standards for use of force, and consistent community engagement rather than simply “defunding” or demonizing police.

As a medical research scientist, I’m acutely aware of how data can both reveal and correct systemic bias, and I believe policing should be guided by rigorous evidence, transparency, and accountability. We need mandatory, ongoing training in de-escalation and implicit bias, clear and enforceable use-of-force standards, and robust data collection and public reporting to monitor disparities and outcomes. Body cameras, independent review boards, and community-based partnerships can help rebuild trust while still allowing officers to protect public safety. Ultimately, a science-informed, rights-respecting approach to policing is not only more just, it’s also more effective at preventing harm for everyone involved.

As a 76-year-old retired artist and lifelong Democrat, I believe policing must be rooted in dignity, accountability, and compassion, with strong oversight to address racial bias and excessive use of force. We need better training in de-escalation and mental health, stricter consequences for misconduct, and a real shift of resources toward community services that prevent crime—like housing, treatment, and education—while still ensuring officers can respond swiftly to serious threats.

As someone who believes in both personal freedom and justice, I think policing needs strong accountability and transparency measures—like body cameras, independent review boards, and firm consequences for misconduct—to reduce bias and excessive use of force. At the same time, as a dad who wants my kids to grow up safe, I support well-trained officers who get ongoing de-escalation, mental health, and bias training, along with enough resources to respond quickly and effectively when there’s real danger. Building trust through community engagement—especially in neighborhoods that feel over-policed or unfairly targeted—is key to maintaining public safety without sacrificing people’s rights.

As someone who works in national security and believes in law and order, I think we absolutely need to address bias and excessive force in policing, but we have to do it in a way that doesn’t undermine officers who put their lives on the line every day. The focus should be on better training in de-escalation, mental health, and cultural awareness, along with clear, consistently enforced standards and body camera use—backed by leadership that supports good cops and removes bad ones quickly. We should use data to identify problem patterns and departments, but any reforms have to be grounded in facts, not politics, and must keep public safety and officer safety at the center.

As someone who values both order and fairness, I believe policing needs stronger, standardized training on de-escalation and implicit bias, paired with clear, consistently enforced accountability for excessive force. At the same time, officers deserve support, adequate staffing, and community backing so they can do their jobs safely and effectively. Independent review of serious incidents and transparent reporting can help rebuild trust, while community policing and regular dialogue with residents keep public safety a shared responsibility, not an us-versus-them dynamic.

As someone who has spent a lifetime teaching young people and believes deeply in fairness and community, I think policing must be grounded in strong accountability, de-escalation training, and clear consequences for bias and excessive force. At the same time, officers should be given the support, resources, and training they need to build trust with the neighborhoods they serve—especially communities that have historically been mistreated. Investments in mental health responders, community outreach, and better screening and education for officers can reduce unnecessary violence while still keeping everyone safe.

I believe most police officers are good people doing a hard job, and we need to support them while also holding them to high, consistent standards. We should invest in better training on de-escalation and recognizing bias, make body cameras standard, and ensure clear, fair consequences when force is misused. At the same time, departments need enough staffing, resources, and community backing so officers can respond quickly and confidently to real threats. That balance—strong accountability and strong support—is how we keep both our families and our freedoms safe.

I respect the tough job that police officers have, and I want them to be supported and well-trained so they can keep our communities safe, including my kids. At the same time, I think departments should use body cameras, better de-escalation training, and clearer use-of-force policies so there’s accountability when things go wrong. We don’t need to “defund” police, but we do need to weed out bad cops and make sure everyone is treated fairly no matter who they are. That way, law-abiding people can trust the police, and officers can do their jobs without being second-guessed for doing the right thing.

As someone who believes in law and order and respects the tough job cops do, I still think we need clear, consistent standards for use of force and real accountability when officers cross the line. Good training that focuses on de-escalation, recognizing unconscious bias, and community engagement can help prevent bad situations before they turn deadly. At the same time, we can’t handcuff the police from doing their jobs—leaders should support officers who follow the rules while firmly removing those who abuse their power. That balance is how we protect both public safety and people’s rights.

I believe most police officers are good people trying to do a tough job, and we need to support them so they can keep our communities safe. At the same time, departments should offer better training on de-escalation, clear standards for when force is appropriate, and fair treatment of everyone, regardless of background. We don’t need to “defund” the police, but we do need strong leadership, accountability, and community involvement so that officers are respected and trusted, not feared.

As a teacher and a mom, I want my kids and my students to feel safe both in our schools and in our neighborhoods, and that means we need policing that is fair, well-trained, and accountable. We should invest in de-escalation training, strong bias screening and oversight, body cameras, and clear, consistently enforced consequences for misuse of force, while also shifting some responsibilities—like mental health crises and homelessness—toward properly funded social services. I don’t see this as “anti-police”; it’s about giving officers the support, training, and guardrails they need so that everyone in the community, especially people of color and other marginalized groups, can trust that the law is applied equally.

As someone who works every day to protect vulnerable animals, I believe policing should follow the same basic principle: minimize harm while safeguarding everyone’s wellbeing. That means mandatory de-escalation and bias training with real accountability, independent review of use-of-force incidents, and shifting many mental health, homelessness, and nonviolent calls to specialized civilian responders. We can maintain public safety more effectively by investing in communities—education, healthcare, housing—so police aren’t the default solution for every social problem, especially in marginalized neighborhoods that have historically endured the brunt of biased policing.

I think police should have to follow strict rules about when they can use force, and they should get in serious trouble if they treat people unfairly because of their race or how they look. At the same time, I want them to be trained to calm situations down instead of going straight to violence, so kids like me can feel safe walking around our neighborhoods. Police should also spend more time actually talking with the community, especially young people, so we see them as helpers and not as people to be scared of.

I back the police because I know they’ve got a tough, dangerous job, but I also think nobody should be above the law, including officers. We need more body cams, better training on de-escalation and bias, and real accountability when someone crosses the line. That way, good cops are protected, bad ones are weeded out, and folks like me can feel safer on the road and in our communities without feeling like our rights are getting trampled.

As someone who works with his hands, raises kids, and just wants them safe, I think we need cops who are well-trained, held accountable, and actually know the communities they serve. Bias and excessive force are real problems, especially for people of color, so I support better training in de-escalation and cultural awareness, plus body cams and clear consequences when officers cross the line. At the same time, we need enough officers and resources so they can respond quickly and effectively to real threats, because good policing and public safety go hand in hand.

As someone who’s lived a long life, taught many children, and seen both progress and painful setbacks, I believe policing must be grounded in accountability, transparency, and respect for every person’s dignity. We should require rigorous de-escalation and anti-bias training, collect and publicly share detailed use-of-force data, and ensure independent investigations when harm occurs—while also funding mental health services and community-based programs that prevent crime before it happens. Maintaining public safety and reducing bias are not competing goals; building trust through fair, evidence-based practices makes everyone safer, including the officers.

As a conservative, law-and-order–minded Catholic who cares deeply about both justice and human dignity, I believe we need to support our police while insisting on high professional standards, better training, and strong accountability for misuse of force. Investments in de‑escalation training, body cameras, and community-based policing can reduce bias and build trust without tying officers’ hands when they need to act quickly to protect the public. I also think we should focus on consistent enforcement of existing laws, clearer use-of-force guidelines, and better mental health and social services partnerships so officers aren’t asked to handle every societal problem alone.

As a 72-year-old Black man who’s lived his whole life in this country, I’ve seen how bias and excessive force from police can damage trust, especially in communities of color, without actually making anyone safer. We need real accountability—body cameras on and reviewed, independent investigations into shootings, and clear consequences for misconduct—paired with better training in de-escalation and conflict resolution. At the same time, officers should be rooted in the neighborhoods they serve, working with community organizations and focusing on serious crime instead of over-policing minor issues. That balance—firm oversight plus genuine partnership—is how you protect both people’s rights and their safety.

I back the men and women in blue and know they’ve got a dangerous job, but I also think we need solid, consistent training to cut down on bias and keep use of force in check. Things like better de-escalation tactics, body cameras, and clear consequences for officers who step out of line can help build trust without tying the hands of the good cops. We should focus on hiring high-character people, supporting them with good pay and mental health resources, and making sure the laws and politicians have their backs when they do the job right.

My mom and dad always tell me that police should help everyone feel safe and be kind, no matter what they look like. I think grown-ups should make sure police learn to calm scary situations down without hurting people unless they really have to, and that they tell the truth when they do something wrong.

As a young dad and a liberal from Wisconsin, I want my family to be safe, but I also don’t want anyone—especially people of color or those from minority backgrounds like mine—treated unfairly by the police. Policing should focus on strong community relationships, mandatory de-escalation and bias training, and clear accountability when officers misuse force. If we invest more in mental health services, youth programs, and community resources, officers won’t be the first or only response to every problem, which makes everyone safer. Public safety and civil rights shouldn’t be in conflict—we can and should demand both.

As someone who’s spent a career in law enforcement, I believe we need firm, consistent standards on use of force, backed by body cameras, good supervision, and solid training that emphasizes judgment and de-escalation—but also makes it clear that officers will be supported when they act within policy. Bias should be addressed with practical, scenario-based training and better hiring and mentoring, not politics or blanket accusations against the whole profession. We owe it to the public to treat everyone fairly and respectfully, and we owe it to officers to give them the tools, staffing, and backing they need to confront real threats and keep communities safe.

As a retired artist and lifelong Pennsylvanian, I believe we need policing that is firmly rooted in accountability, de-escalation, and respect for the dignity of every person, regardless of race or background. That means better training to recognize and reduce bias, strict and transparent review of use-of-force incidents, and stronger community oversight so people feel the police are working with them, not against them. At the same time, officers should have the resources, mental health support, and clear policies they need to do their jobs safely and effectively. Public safety and civil rights are not in conflict—we can and must insist on both.

As a physician working in a hospital where I see the physical and psychological consequences of excessive force, I believe policing strategies must prioritize de-escalation, rigorous bias training, and strong accountability mechanisms, including independent review of use-of-force incidents. At the same time, officers need sufficient support, training, and resources to safely manage genuinely dangerous situations, because public safety and civil rights are not opposing goals. Community-based policing—where officers know the people they serve, engage transparently, and build trust—can reduce both bias and violence, ultimately creating safer neighborhoods for everyone.

As a young Navajo mom raising kids in a country where people who look like us and our relatives of color are often over-policed, I want safer communities without feeling like we have to be scared of the people who are supposed to protect us. Police should be trained deeply on de-escalation, bias, and our communities’ histories, and there need to be real consequences when they use force unnecessarily. We also need more funding for mental health services, youth programs, and community-based responders so officers aren’t the only answer to every problem. Public safety should mean everyone—especially Native and Black and Brown people—can walk around without feeling like a target.

As someone who came here from Mexico, is now raising kids in this community, and believes deeply in fairness, I think policing has to be rooted in respect, transparency, and strong accountability when bias or excessive force occurs. Officers should get real, ongoing training in de-escalation and cultural understanding, and they should build relationships with the neighborhoods they serve, not just show up when there’s trouble. We can be safe without giving up people’s dignity and rights, especially for communities of color and immigrants who too often feel targeted.

As someone who cares deeply about both my kids’ safety and the well-being of our broader community, I think policing needs to prioritize de-escalation training, strict accountability for misconduct, and transparent data on stops and use of force, broken down by race and neighborhood. We should invest heavily in community-based alternatives—mental health responders, youth programs, and social services—so police aren’t the default answer to every problem, while still ensuring they have the training and support to handle truly dangerous situations.

As someone who works in tech and cares about both safety and fairness, I think policing needs stronger accountability measures—body cameras, transparent investigations, and real consequences for excessive force—alongside rigorous, ongoing bias and de-escalation training. We should invest more in community-based programs and mental health responders so police aren’t the default for every problem, while still ensuring they have the resources and standards needed to respond quickly and professionally to serious threats.

I’m little, so I mostly just want everyone to feel safe, including my mom and my friends. I think police should be really careful and gentle, learn about different kinds of people and families like mine, and only use force when they absolutely have to. Grown‑ups should help teach police how to be fair and kind so kids don’t have to be scared of them and can ask them for help.

At my age, I’ve seen enough to know that real public safety depends on trust, and you don’t build trust when certain communities live in fear of the very people sworn to protect them. We need stricter national standards on use of force, independent investigations of misconduct, and ongoing anti-bias training rooted in actual community experience, not just PowerPoint slides. At the same time, officers deserve proper support, clear rules, and the expectation that de-escalation is the default whenever possible. If we invest in mental health services, community programs, and accountable policing together, we can reduce both crime and unnecessary violence.

I think police should try really hard to be kind and fair to everyone, no matter what they look like, and only use force when there is no other way to keep people safe. They should learn to calm down scary situations by talking and listening first, kind of like how my teachers help when kids argue. My religion teaches compassion, so I feel like officers should practice understanding people’s feelings and mistakes instead of hurting them. That way, our neighborhoods can feel safe and people can trust the police more.

My mommy and daddy say that police should be nice and fair to everyone, and not hurt people just because they look different. I think police should try talking and helping first so everyone feels safe, and only use force if they really have to. I feel better when grown-ups are kind and careful, like the people at church say Jesus wants us to be.

As a teacher and a mom, I want my kids to grow up in a community where they can trust the police and also feel safe walking down the street, no matter who they are. We need stronger bias training, real accountability for misconduct, body cameras that are always on, and clear limits on use of force—especially deadly force—backed by independent review. At the same time, we should invest more in mental health services, school counselors, and community programs so officers aren’t expected to solve every social problem with a badge and a gun. That balance—firm accountability paired with smart prevention—is how we protect both public safety and people’s rights.

As a young woman of mixed race who’s grown up seeing both the good and bad sides of policing, I think we need stricter accountability and transparency around use of force, along with strong bias and de-escalation training, so officers are taught to see the people they serve as neighbors, not threats. At the same time, I do want to feel safe walking home from work at night, so I support community-based policing where officers build real relationships with residents and focus on prevention and problem-solving, not just punishment.

As a young mom and a woman of color, I want my family and community to feel both protected and respected, so I believe policing has to center on de-escalation, bias training, and real accountability when officers abuse their power. We need more community-based approaches—like mental health responders, youth programs, and officers who actually know and serve the neighborhoods they patrol—so that calling the police doesn’t feel like a risk, especially for people of color.

As someone who’s grown up and worked around all kinds of people, I think policing has to be rooted in community relationships and real accountability if it’s going to be fair and keep us safe. We need better training to reduce bias and de-escalate situations, strict consequences when officers misuse force, and more investment in mental health and social services so cops aren’t the only answer to every problem.

I think police should try really hard to treat everyone fairly and not judge people because of what they look like or where they come from, because in my church we learn that everyone is equal before God. They should get more training on calming people down without hurting them, but also still be there to protect us when something dangerous happens so kids and families can feel safe in their neighborhoods.

Como alguien que valora el orden, la familia y el respeto, pienso que la policía es necesaria para mantenernos seguros, pero también debe tratar a todos con justicia, sin importar nuestro color de piel, idioma o país de origen. Necesitan mejor entrenamiento para controlar el coraje, evitar el uso excesivo de fuerza y aprender a conocer a la comunidad, especialmente a los inmigrantes que muchas veces tenemos miedo de llamarles. Para mí, lo ideal es que los policías trabajen con las iglesias, las familias y los vecinos, para que haya confianza y se puedan resolver problemas sin tanta violencia.

As a retired public school teacher and a law-abiding citizen, I believe we need strong, well-supported police forces, but we also need clear standards and accountability so that everyone is treated fairly. Good training in de-escalation, firm discipline for truly bad actors, and body cameras can help address bias and use-of-force problems without tying officers’ hands. I want officers to feel backed by their communities and leaders when they do their jobs right, and I want citizens to know they’ll be protected and respected, regardless of who they are.

As someone who believes in law and order but also in treating people fairly, I think policing should focus on solid training, including de-escalation and bias awareness, while still giving officers the support and tools they need to do a tough job. We should hold bad actors accountable through body cameras and clear use-of-force policies, but not paint all officers with the same brush. Strong relationships between police and the community, like regular neighborhood meetings and visibility, can help build trust so officers can keep us safe without people feeling targeted or disrespected.

I support the police and believe they’re essential for keeping our communities safe, but I also think they need clear, strict standards on when force is acceptable and real consequences when officers cross the line. We should invest in better training on de-escalation and bias, use body cameras consistently, and have outside review when serious incidents happen, so both the public and good officers are protected.

As a 77-year-old Black man who’s seen both the worst and the best of this country, I believe policing has to be rooted in respect for human dignity, strict accountability, and real community partnership. We need mandatory de-escalation and anti-bias training with teeth, independent investigations of use-of-force, body cameras that are always on, and clear consequences when officers violate policy. At the same time, real public safety comes from investing in mental health services, youth programs, and jobs in our neighborhoods, so officers aren’t asked to solve every social problem with a badge and a gun. When police and communities stand on equal footing, with transparency and mutual trust, everyone is safer.

I believe most police officers are trying to do a difficult job and keep our communities safe, but we still need clear, consistent standards to prevent bias and unnecessary use of force. I’d support better training in de-escalation and mental health, body cameras that are actually used and reviewed, and strong, fair consequences when officers cross the line. At the same time, we need to make sure officers have the resources, staffing, and community backing they need so they can respond quickly and effectively when crime happens. Balancing accountability with support for law enforcement is the best way to protect both our rights and our safety.

As both a nurse practitioner and a mom, I want my kids to grow up in a community where they can trust the police and where everyone is treated fairly, regardless of race or background. We should focus on strong de-escalation training, data-driven accountability for use-of-force, and pairing officers with mental health and social service professionals so police aren’t asked to solve every problem with a badge and a gun. At the same time, we need to give good officers the support, staffing, and training they need to respond quickly and safely when people are genuinely in danger.

Policing needs to be fundamentally reoriented toward transparency, accountability, and de-escalation, with data-driven oversight to identify and correct patterns of racial bias and excessive force. As someone who lives by words and evidence, I want policies that mandate body cameras, independent civilian review boards with real power, and rigorous training in implicit bias and mental health response—paired with shifting some responsibilities (like crisis intervention and homelessness) to specialized social services. Public safety is best protected when communities actually trust law enforcement, and that means officers must be held to clear, consistently enforced standards that value every life equally.

Como mujer mexicana, madre y miembro activa de mi comunidad, creo que la policía debe enfocarse en la prevención, el respeto y la humanidad antes que en la fuerza. Se necesitan entrenamientos serios en sesgos raciales y culturales, más transparencia (como cámaras corporales y reportes públicos), y mayor inversión en servicios sociales y de salud mental para que no todo se resuelva con arrestos. También es importante que haya más oficiales que vengan de nuestras propias comunidades y que existan mecanismos reales para responsabilizar a quienes abusan de su poder, porque la seguridad verdadera se construye con confianza, no con miedo.

As someone who works in public safety IT and cares deeply about my community, I believe we need policing strategies that both protect officers and the public while holding everyone to high standards. We should invest in better training on de-escalation, consistent use-of-force policies, and body cameras to increase transparency, but also make sure officers have the resources and support they need to do a dangerous job. I support fair accountability for misconduct, but I don’t believe in weakening law enforcement to the point where families like mine feel less safe in their own neighborhoods.

As a Black woman, a mom, and a school employee, I want police to keep our kids and communities safe, but they need to do it in a way that respects our lives and our dignity. We need strong bias training, real accountability when officers use excessive force, and more investment in mental health and community-based responses so cops aren’t sent to handle every problem. When officers actually know the neighborhoods and the people they serve, and we have transparency about what they do, it builds trust instead of fear.

As someone who cares deeply about community well‑being and fairness, I believe policing strategies need to prioritize de-escalation, implicit bias training, and transparent accountability so that force is truly a last resort. We can maintain public safety by investing in mental health responders, community-based programs, and better officer screening and training, while also using body cameras and independent review boards to build trust. As a small business owner, I want safe neighborhoods, but I also want to know that everyone—regardless of race or background—is treated with dignity and respect.

I think police officers should be trained a lot more on how to treat everyone fairly, no matter what they look like, and how to calm situations down without using force unless it’s absolutely necessary. Since I really believe in learning and facts, I also think there should be clear rules, body cameras, and public reports about when force is used so people can see what’s really happening and trust the system more.

As someone who cares deeply about both fairness and safety in my community, I believe policing needs stronger accountability, better de‑escalation and bias training, and clear limits on use of force so everyone is treated with dignity. At the same time, officers should be supported with good training, mental health resources, and community partnerships—like working with local centers and schools—so they can prevent crime without resorting to violence.

As someone who cares about both public safety and civil rights, I think policing needs stronger accountability measures—like mandatory body cameras, independent review boards, and real consequences for excessive force—alongside better training in de-escalation and implicit bias. We ask officers to do a hard job, but that can’t excuse patterns of violence and discrimination, especially against communities of color. I’d like to see more community-based approaches to safety, where social workers and mental health professionals handle appropriate calls, and police focus on serious threats. That balance—firm oversight, less militarization, and more collaboration—would make me feel safer in my own neighborhood and more trusting of law enforcement.

As someone who teaches and thinks a lot about evidence and ethics, I believe policing strategies must be grounded in rigorous data, bias training that actually changes behavior, and clear, consistently enforced limits on use of force. We should invest heavily in alternatives to armed response—such as mental health and social service teams—while using transparent accountability measures (body cameras, independent review boards, public reporting) to rebuild trust. Public safety is best protected when communities, especially those historically over-policed, feel respected and heard rather than surveilled and threatened.

I believe most police officers are trying to do a hard job well, and we need to support them while also insisting on fairness and accountability. Clear standards on use of force, better training in de-escalation, and body cameras can help address bias and rebuild trust without tying officers’ hands. Local communities should be involved in setting priorities and reviewing serious incidents, but we should be careful not to demonize the whole profession based on the actions of a few. Public safety and respect for everyone’s rights ought to go hand in hand.

As someone who believes in both accountability and practical public safety, I think policing strategies need to prioritize de-escalation training, strict use-of-force standards, and real transparency when incidents occur, including independent review of serious cases. We should invest more in community-based approaches and mental health professionals so police aren’t the default for every social problem, while still ensuring that officers have the resources and training they need to handle genuinely dangerous situations. Addressing bias—through data-driven oversight, body cameras, and consequences for misconduct—isn’t “anti-police”; it’s how we build the trust that makes everyone safer, including good officers doing a difficult job.

As a progressive, family-oriented teacher, I want my kids and my students to grow up in communities where they can trust the police and also feel truly safe. We need stronger de-escalation training, meaningful accountability for misconduct, and independent oversight to address bias and excessive force, alongside investments in mental health services, youth programs, and community-based interventions that prevent crime before it happens. To me, public safety isn’t just about law enforcement presence; it’s about building relationships, reducing inequality, and making sure every person—regardless of race or neighborhood—is treated with dignity and fairness.

As someone who values both fairness and safety, I believe policing needs strong, enforced standards that minimize bias and unnecessary use of force—things like better training in de-escalation, more diverse hiring, and independent oversight. We should invest more in mental health services and community-based programs so police aren’t the default response to every problem, but I still want them well-trained and well-supported to handle real threats. Body cameras, transparent reporting, and real accountability when officers misuse force are essential for rebuilding trust between police and the communities they serve.

As someone who’s seen a lot of changes over 75 years, I believe we can have both safe communities and fair, accountable policing if we’re willing to be honest about bias and hold officers to high standards. Police should get strong de-escalation and bias training, wear body cameras, and face real consequences when they abuse their power, while also working closely with neighborhoods so people feel protected, not targeted. I’d like to see more funding for mental health and social services so officers aren’t the only ones responding to every crisis, and so force truly becomes a last resort.

As someone who spends her life trying to move people through music, I believe policing should be rooted in de-escalation, cultural competence, and a deep respect for human dignity, with clear accountability when officers abuse their power. We need stronger bias training, independent investigations into use-of-force incidents, and a shift in resources toward mental health services and community-based programs so that officers aren’t the blunt instrument for every social problem. That said, I recognize the importance of public safety, and I think the most effective way to achieve it is for police to work in genuine partnership with the communities they serve, not in opposition to them.

As a Black woman, a veteran, and someone who works closely with vulnerable people every day, I believe policing has to prioritize de-escalation, cultural competency, and strict accountability for misconduct if we’re serious about reducing bias and unnecessary use of force. We need better training, stronger community oversight, and investment in mental health and social services so officers aren’t the default response to every crisis. At the same time, I want my community to be safe, so I support officers who follow the rules, respect people’s rights, and build genuine relationships with the neighborhoods they serve.

As a lifelong educator and active community member, I believe policing strategies must start with rigorous de-escalation training, implicit bias education, and strict accountability for excessive force, especially in communities of color that have historically borne the brunt of misconduct. Public safety is best protected when officers are trained to see themselves as partners with the community, supported by well-funded mental health and social services so that police aren’t the default response to every crisis. I’d like to see more transparency in data on stops and use of force, along with civilian review boards that actually have teeth, so trust can be rebuilt on all sides.

As someone who values both community wellness and public safety, I believe policing strategies must prioritize de-escalation, strong bias training, and strict accountability for excessive force, including independent oversight and transparent investigations. We need to invest more in mental health services, social workers, and community-based programs so that not every crisis is answered with an armed response. At the same time, officers should be well-trained, fairly compensated, and supported so they can build trust with the communities they serve rather than relying on fear or intimidation.

As someone who cares deeply about safety for my family and community, I believe we need strong, well-supported police departments, but also clear standards to prevent abuse and bias. We should invest in better training on de-escalation, mental health, and cultural awareness, along with body cameras and strong leadership that holds bad actors accountable. At the same time, officers need the tools, staffing, and backing to do their jobs effectively so law-abiding citizens feel protected, not abandoned. The goal should be fair, firm policing that treats everyone with dignity while keeping dangerous criminals off the streets.

As a conservative, family-oriented high school teacher, I believe we need policing strategies that both hold officers accountable and allow them to do their jobs effectively. We should invest in better training on de-escalation and bias, ensure body cameras are consistently used and footage reviewed, and enforce clear consequences when officers violate policy. At the same time, we must support law enforcement with the resources, staffing, and public backing they need to keep communities—especially our kids—safe. Balancing firm accountability with strong support for good officers is the best way to reduce use-of-force incidents without sacrificing public safety.

As a teacher and a Democrat, I believe policing should prioritize de-escalation, implicit bias training, and strong accountability measures so that use-of-force is truly a last resort. We need transparent data on stops, arrests, and force, along with independent oversight, to confront patterns of racial bias honestly. At the same time, investing in mental health services, social workers, and community programs can reduce the burden on police and address many issues before they become emergencies. Public safety is strongest when communities trust law enforcement and see them as partners, not threats.

As a lifelong educator and a Democrat who cares deeply about civil rights, I believe policing must be guided by strict accountability, bias training grounded in real data, and transparent community oversight to rebuild trust. We should prioritize de-escalation, mental health responders, and non-lethal options so force is truly a last resort, while still ensuring officers have the support, training, and staffing needed to respond quickly and effectively to serious threats.

As someone who cares a lot about justice and the environment, I think policing needs to be rooted in de-escalation, anti-bias training, and real accountability so communities—especially Black and mixed-race folks—aren’t scared of the people who are supposed to protect them. We should shift resources toward mental health services, youth programs, and community-based violence prevention, and have independent investigations for use-of-force incidents. That way we can keep people safe without turning neighborhoods into war zones or ignoring the systemic racism that’s already there.

As a mom and someone who talks with all kinds of people at the front desk every day, I want police to keep our communities safe, but also to be held to high standards when it comes to bias and use of force. We should invest in better training on de-escalation and cultural awareness, require body cameras and transparent reporting, and make sure there are real consequences when officers step out of line. At the same time, officers need support, good supervision, and enough staffing so they’re not constantly in high-stress situations that can lead to bad decisions. I believe we can back the good work police do while still pushing for reforms that treat everyone fairly and build trust.

As a mom and someone who works in a risk-focused industry, I believe we need policing that is both firm and fair: officers must be able to enforce the law and protect our communities, but they also need strong training, clear rules, and real accountability around bias and use of force. I support more de-escalation training, body cameras, and better screening and support for officers, while still ensuring they have the resources and backing to respond quickly and decisively to genuine threats.

As a liberal, Jewish Texan with a disability and no safety net like health insurance, I’m deeply aware of how vulnerable people can be when systems of power aren’t held accountable. Policing strategies should prioritize de-escalation, implicit bias training, mental health responders, and strong civilian oversight so that force is truly a last resort, not a routine tool—especially in marginalized communities. At the same time, communities deserve to feel safe from violence and crime, which means investing in prevention, social services, and neighborhood-based partnerships that reduce the need for police interventions in the first place.

As a liberal, atheist art director who cares deeply about civil rights and creative expression, I think policing strategies need to prioritize de-escalation, bias training, and accountability mechanisms like body cameras and independent review boards. We can maintain public safety without militarizing neighborhoods by investing in mental health responders, community outreach, and addressing root causes of crime, while setting clear, enforceable limits on use of force and meaningful consequences when officers cross the line.

As someone who cares deeply about my community and public safety, I believe policing must be guided by strong accountability, thorough de-escalation training, and transparent oversight to address bias and excessive use of force. Officers should build relationships through community-based policing and be required to wear body cameras, with clear consequences when misconduct occurs. We also need better mental health and social services so police aren’t the default responders to every crisis. That way, we can both protect people’s rights and keep neighborhoods safe.

As someone who believes deeply in social justice and equality, I think policing has to start with recognizing and correcting systemic bias, especially against communities that have been over-policed for generations. Officers need de-escalation training, strong accountability when force is misused, and real community oversight so people feel protected rather than targeted. At the same time, I want my neighborhood to be safe, so I support investing in mental health services, housing, and jobs alongside fair, restrained policing that treats every person with dignity.

As someone who believes in law and order but also cares about fairness, I think policing has to balance strong public safety with strict accountability. Officers should get better training on de-escalation and recognizing bias, and body cameras should be standard so there’s a clear record of what happens. I don’t support “defund the police,” but I do support higher hiring standards, more community involvement, and serious consequences when officers abuse their power. That way, good cops are backed up, bad cops are removed, and communities can trust the people sworn to protect them.

As a Catholic, a mom, and someone who works with children at our church, I believe we must support our police while also holding them to the highest standards of justice and fairness. We should invest in better training on de-escalation and recognizing bias, clear and consistent accountability for misconduct, and stronger relationships between officers and the communities they serve. At the same time, we can’t undermine law enforcement to the point that families and neighborhoods are left unsafe—public safety and respect for human dignity must go hand in hand.

As a mom and someone who wants my kids to feel safe in our community, I think we need policing that’s both firm and fair—officers should be well-trained in de-escalation, implicit bias, and mental health response, and held accountable when they misuse force. At the same time, we can’t just “defund” safety; we should invest in better training, body cameras, community policing, and independent oversight, while also putting more resources into schools, youth programs, and social services so police aren’t the only answer to every problem.

As a liberal, health-conscious woman who’s lived her whole life in this country, I see policing as a public safety service that should protect everyone equally, not a source of fear—especially for communities of color. We need stricter national standards on use of force, mandatory body cameras, and real accountability when officers abuse their power, paired with strong bias training and better screening before people are even hired. At the same time, I’d like to see more investment in mental health professionals, social workers, and community programs so police aren’t the default responders to every problem. That combination—firm oversight plus smarter, community-centered support—is how we can reduce bias and violence without sacrificing safety.

As someone who manages crews and takes safety seriously, I think cops need clear, strict standards on when force is justified, body cams on all the time, and real consequences when those rules are broken—no special treatment. At the same time, we can’t handcuff the police from doing their job; they need solid training, good pay, and community backing so they can go after real criminals without worrying every split-second decision will get them crucified in the media. Bias should be addressed with better hiring, training, and data transparency, not with political grandstanding that makes streets more dangerous for everyone, including my kids.

As someone who believes in law and order but also in the dignity of every human being, I think policing must be both firm and fair. We should invest in better training that emphasizes de-escalation, respect for all communities, and clear rules on use of force, while also backing officers who follow those rules and put themselves in harm’s way. Independent review of serious incidents, along with body cameras and transparent reporting, can help address bias without undermining the authority officers need to keep our streets safe.

My mommy and daddy say police should be nice to everybody and not hurt people just because they look different, and I think that’s important because it makes me feel safe. I think police should talk and listen first and only use force if someone is really in danger, like if a bad person is trying to hurt people. If police learn in school how to be fair and kind and know our names in the neighborhood, then kids like me won’t be scared of them and they can still keep us safe.

I believe most police officers are good people doing a hard and dangerous job, and they deserve our respect and support. At the same time, departments should weed out bad actors, provide better training on de-escalation and dealing fairly with everyone, and require body cameras so there’s accountability on all sides. We need firm but fair policing, with clear consequences for excessive force, so that law-abiding citizens feel both protected and respected.

As someone who’s lived a long time in this country and seen a lot, I think policing has to change so it treats everyone fairly while still keeping us safe. We need stricter rules and independent oversight on use of force, real consequences when officers abuse their power, and serious training on de‑escalation and implicit bias, not just box‑checking workshops. At the same time, we should invest more in mental health services, social workers, and community programs so cops aren’t the default answer to every problem on the street. Public safety and civil rights aren’t opposites—if people don’t trust the police, nobody’s really safe.

As a mother and someone who works in healthcare, I want policing that treats everyone with the same care and respect we owe our patients—no exceptions. We need mandatory de-escalation and bias training, independent investigations of use-of-force incidents, and stronger community oversight so officers are accountable and trusted. At the same time, we should invest in mental health responders and community programs that prevent crime in the first place, so police aren’t asked to solve every social problem with a badge and a gun. That balance—firm accountability paired with smart prevention—is how we keep both our neighborhoods and our civil rights safe.

As someone who works with all kinds of people every day, I think policing has to be built on respect, de-escalation, and real accountability if we want communities to trust officers and feel safe. We should invest in better training on bias and conflict resolution, more transparency on use-of-force incidents, and shift some responsibilities—like mental health crises—toward trained specialists so cops aren’t trying to do everything. That way we can reduce discrimination and unnecessary violence while still making sure neighborhoods, including families like mine, are protected.

Back in my day, we were taught to respect the police, and I still believe law and order are essential for keeping our communities safe. That said, I think departments should invest in better training on de-escalation and bias, use body cameras consistently, and hold officers accountable when they step out of line. We don’t need to “defund” the police, but we do need clear standards, strong leadership, and community involvement so good officers are supported and bad behavior is not brushed under the rug.

As someone who values individual liberty and public safety, I think policing needs more transparency, better training in de-escalation, and strong accountability measures to address bias and use-of-force without tying officers’ hands when real danger is present. We should use data and body cam footage the way I use diagnostics in my job—identify patterns, fix what’s broken, and upgrade what works—rather than relying on politics or gut feelings. I support policies that treat everyone equally under the law, but I also want officers to have clear rules of engagement and the tools they need to go home safe at the end of their shifts.

As a Christian, a mom, and someone deeply involved in community work, I believe policing must be rooted in dignity, accountability, and a genuine commitment to protecting all people equally. We need strong bias training, transparent use-of-force policies, and independent oversight so that officers who misuse power are held accountable, while also ensuring police have the support, training, and community partnerships they need to respond safely and effectively.

As a mom and a working professional, I want my kids to feel safe calling the police, but I also want to know that officers are being held to clear, consistent standards that apply to everyone, no matter their race or neighborhood. We need stronger de‑escalation training, real accountability for excessive force, and independent investigations when things go wrong, so trust isn’t just talked about but actually earned. I don’t think public safety and fairness are opposites—if anything, bias-free, community-focused policing makes everyone safer, including good officers who are trying to do their jobs the right way.

As someone who cares deeply about community, mental health, and justice, I think policing strategies need to center de-escalation, anti-bias training, and real accountability while shifting many calls—like mental health crises and homelessness—away from armed officers to specialized responders. We can still maintain public safety, but it should be done with strict limits on use of force, body-camera transparency, strong civilian oversight, and investment in social services that actually prevent harm instead of just reacting to it.

My mommy says police should be fair and kind to everybody, no matter what they look like, so kids like me don’t have to be scared. I think police should learn to talk and listen more instead of hurting people, so they can keep us safe and we can still trust them.

As a construction manager and small business owner, I depend on safe communities and I respect the tough job police officers do every day. I think we need strong support and funding for law enforcement, but also consistent training on de-escalation, clear body camera policies, and accountability when officers cross the line. We can address bias and use-of-force concerns with better hiring standards, ongoing professional training, and firm leadership, without tying the hands of good cops who keep our neighborhoods safe.

As a teacher and a Catholic, I believe our policing strategies must prioritize the dignity of every person while still keeping our communities safe. We need strong accountability measures—like body cameras, transparent investigations, and independent oversight—alongside rigorous, ongoing training in de-escalation, bias awareness, and mental health response. At the same time, cities should invest more in social services, education, and community-based programs, so officers aren’t asked to solve every problem with the blunt tool of enforcement. That balance—firm standards, real oversight, and robust community support—is the best way to reduce bias and excessive force without sacrificing public safety.

As a progressive Catholic and someone who works with data and systems every day, I believe policing needs evidence-based reforms that reduce bias and excessive force while still keeping communities safe. That means mandatory de-escalation and implicit bias training, body cameras with real accountability, independent review of serious incidents, and rethinking what we ask police to handle—shifting mental health and some nonviolent calls to specialized responders. I want officers to be partners with the community, not an occupying presence, and I think we can use technology and good policy together to build trust without sacrificing safety.
